title: fix: correct post-delete finalizer removal when cluster not found
body:
Fixes: https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/19571

When an Application with post-delete hooks cannot find its destination cluster, the controller was calling UnSetPostDeleteFinalizer() without the "cleanup" stage parameter. This caused the finalizer removal to fail silently because the actual finalizer name includes the stage (post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup), but the code was trying to remove the base finalizer name (post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io).

This resulted in an reconciliation loop where the controller would repeatedly attempt to clean up the application but fail to remove the finalizer, preventing the application from being deleted.

The fix ensures that both the base finalizer and the cleanup stage finalizer are properly removed when the destination cluster cannot be found.

title: fix: argocd incorrectly logging PermissionDenied
body:
…xist

- Improve error message parsing to distinguish between permission denied and chart not found errors
- Only report PermissionDenied when repository access is actually denied, not when chart version doesn't exist
- Fixes issue #24386

The issue was that ArgoCD would incorrectly report PermissionDenied errors when a Helm chart version didn't exist, even when the repository was properly permitted in the project. This fix improves the error message parsing logic to distinguish between actual permission issues and chart-not-found scenarios.

title: chore(deps): bump github.com/redis/go-redis/v9 from 9.8.0 to 9.13.0
body:
Bumps [github.com/redis/go-redis/v9](https://github.com/redis/go-redis) from 9.8.0 to 9.13.0.
Release notes

Sourced from github.com/redis/go-redis/v9's releases.

9.13.0

Highlights

  • Pipeliner expose queued commands (#3496)
  • Ensure that JSON.GET returns Nil response (#3470)
  • Fixes on Read and Write buffer sizes and UniversalOptions

Changes

  • Pipeliner expose queued commands (#3496)
  • fix(test): fix a timing issue in pubsub test (#3498)
  • Allow users to enable read-write splitting in failover mode. (#3482)
  • Set the read/write buffer size of the sentinel client to 4KiB (#3476)

🚀 New Features

  • fix(otel): register wait metrics (#3499)
  • Support subscriptions against cluster slave nodes (#3480)
  • Add wait metrics to otel (#3493)
  • Clean failing timeout implementation (#3472)

🐛 Bug Fixes

  • Do not assume that all non-IP hosts are loopbacks (#3085)
  • Ensure that JSON.GET returns Nil response (#3470)

🧰 Maintenance

  • fix(otel): register wait metrics (#3499)
  • fix(make test): Add default env in makefile (#3491)
  • Update the introduction to running tests in README.md (#3495)
  • test: Add comprehensive edge case tests for IncrByFloat command (#3477)
  • Set the default read/write buffer size of Redis connection to 32KiB (#3483)
  • Bumps test image to 8.2.1-pre (#3478)
  • fix UniversalOptions miss ReadBufferSize and WriteBufferSize options (#3485)
  • chore(deps): bump actions/checkout from 4 to 5 (#3484)
  • Removes dry run for stale issues policy (#3471)
  • Update otel metrics URL (#3474)

Contributors

We'd like to thank all the contributors who worked on this release!

@​LINKIWI, @​cxljs, @​cybersmeashish, @​elena-kolevska, @​htemelski-redis, @​mwhooker, @​ndyakov, @​ofekshenawa, @​suever

9.12.1

🚀 Highlights

In the last version (9.12.0) the client introduced bigger write and read buffer sizes. The default value was 512KiB. However, users reported that this is too big for most use cases and can lead to high memory usage. In this version the default value is changed to 256KiB. The README.md was updated to reflect the correct default value and include a note that the default value can be changed.

🐛 Bug Fixes

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from github.com/redis/go-redis/v9's changelog.

9.13.0 (2025-09-03)

Highlights

  • Pipeliner expose queued commands (#3496)
  • Ensure that JSON.GET returns Nil response (#3470)
  • Fixes on Read and Write buffer sizes and UniversalOptions

Changes

  • Pipeliner expose queued commands (#3496)
  • fix(test): fix a timing issue in pubsub test (#3498)
  • Allow users to enable read-write splitting in failover mode. (#3482)
  • Set the read/write buffer size of the sentinel client to 4KiB (#3476)

🚀 New Features

  • Support subscriptions against cluster slave nodes (#3480)
  • Add wait metrics to otel (#3493)
  • Clean failing timeout implementation (#3472)

🐛 Bug Fixes

  • fix UniversalOptions miss ReadBufferSize and WriteBufferSize options (#3485)
  • chore(deps): bump actions/checkout from 4 to 5 (#3484)
  • Removes dry run for stale issues policy (#3471)
  • Update otel metrics URL (#3474)

Contributors

We'd like to thank all the contributors who worked on this release!

@​LINKIWI, @​cxljs, @​cybersmeashish, @​elena-kolevska, @​htemelski-redis, @​mwhooker, @​ndyakov, @​ofekshenawa, @​suever

9.12.1 (2025-08-11)

🚀 Highlights

In the last version (9.12.0) the client introduced bigger write and read buffer sized. The default value we set was 512KiB. However, users reported that this is too big for most use cases and can lead to high memory usage. In this version the default value is changed to 256KiB. The README.md was updated to reflect the correct default value and include a note that the default value can be changed.

Full Changelog: https://github.com/spf13/pflag/compare/v1.0.8...v1.0.9

v1.0.8

:warning: Breaking Change

This version, while only a patch bump, includes a (very minor) breaking change: the flag.ParseErrorsWhitelist struct and corresponding FlagSet.parseErrorsWhitelist field have been renamed to ParseErrorsAllowlist.

This should result in compilation errors in any code that uses these fields, which can be fixed by adjusting the names at call sites. There is no change in semantics or behavior of the struct or field referred to by these names. If your code compiles without errors after bumping to/past v1.0.8, you are not affected by this change.

The breaking change was reverted in v1.0.9, by means of re-introducing the old names with deprecation warnings. The plan is still to remove them in a future release, so if your code does depend on the old names, please change them to use the new names at your earliest convenience.

title: feat: pause actions disabled when owned by a Numaplane rollout
body:
<!--
Note on DCO:

If the DCO action in the integration test fails, one or more of your commits are not signed off. Please click on the *Details* link next to the DCO action for instructions on how to resolve this. Numaplane will also override changes directly made on the Pipeline or MonoVertex via self-healing which will cause issues if we are using the actions on the children.
-->

Disables the pausing actions on a Pipeline or MonoVertex if it is owned by a parent Numaplane rollout.

Motivation for this is to prevent confusion for the user as to why they can pause and unpause the same resource via the rollout or the child itself. If it is owned by a rollout, we would prefer users use those actions. Numaplane will also override changes directly made on the Pipeline or MonoVertex via self-healing which will cause issues if we are using the actions on the children.

title: fix(hydrator): Fix namespace handling and add missing tracking IDs in hydrated manifests
body:
<!--
Note on DCO:

If the DCO action in the integration test fails, one or more of your commits are not signed off. Please click on the *Details* link next to the DCO action for instructions on how to resolve this.
-->
closes (#24371)
**Problem Solved:**

The current hydrated manifest.yaml does not always include the correct namespace or tracking ID. This causes a gap between what’s shown in hydrated manifests and what Argo CD actually deploys, reducing observability and making debugging harder. Specifically:

  - Hydrated manifests lacked argocd.argoproj.io/tracking-id annotations that Argo CD adds to deployed resources.
  - For namespace-scoped resources (ServiceAccount, Pod, ConfigMap), when spec.namespace="", hydrated manifests showed no namespace, even though Argo CD would deploy them into the application’s destination namespace.
  - For cluster-scoped resources, if a namespace was mistakenly specified by the user, it still appeared in hydrated manifests, even though Argo CD would later remove it during deployment, creating confusion.

 **What This PR Does:**

  - Ensures hydrated manifests always include the correct namespace (derived from the app’s destination for namespace-scoped resources).
  - Cleans up incorrectly specified namespaces on cluster-scoped resources.  
  - Ensures all hydrated resources include the argocd.argoproj.io/tracking-id annotation.

  
![namespace and tracking id](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/93ded142-6e08-4b13-9237-569c3588cde0)


**Why It’s Necessary:**

  - Improved observability: Hydrated manifests now reflect the actual deployed state.
  - Easier monitoring: Tracking IDs make it simpler to correlate resources with events, logs, and metrics.
  - Convenience: Simplifies debugging and management of hydrated resources across environments.

title: fix: allow Directory + Plugin source type combinations for app-of-app issue

…s patterns

- Add HasValidSourceTypeCombination method to validate source type combinations
- Allow Directory + Plugin combinations (for scanning directories and processing with plugins)

- Fixes GitHub issue #24350: 'Multiple application sources defined: Directory,Plugin'

This change enables the app-of-apps pattern to work with plugins like Helmwave, allowing users to scan directories for Application manifests and process them through config management plugins.

title: [Bot] docs: Update Snyk report
chore(refactor): move ignoreResourceUpdates defaults into code
body:
Partially fixes https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/24394

This moves one of the groups of default configuration that currently resides in argocd-cm into code to align with how other config options work.

The defaults are published in the docs for easy reference: https://argo-cd--24330.org.readthedocs.build/en/24330/operator-manual/reconcile/#system-level-configuration

This is a minor breaking change. If someone has removed one or more of the default configs' keys from argocd-cm, this change will cause the defaults to start being used. The workaround would be for the user to set the key in argocd-cm but make the value an empty string.

title: feat(ui): Add hydration in status to dashboard application tiles
body: **Problem:** Currently, there is no immediate visual feedback on the main dashboard for an Application's source hydration status. Users must click into the application details page to know if a hydration process is running, has completed successfully, or has failed. This PR improves the user experience by exposing the hydration status directly on the application tiles, providing at-a-glance visibility. **What This PR Does** Adds a Hydration Status Icon: A new icon is displayed on the application tile only if the application uses a sourceHydrator. Shows Different States: The icon and its tooltip change to reflect the current hydration phase: (Hydrating, Hydrated, Failed) Edit: Added Hydration Status in List and Summary tab in this commit bae46a4f8e7b5912f4bbd2f0345ba5a55761d8e7 Checklist: * [ ] Either (a) I've created an [enhancement proposal](https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/new/choose) and discussed it with the community, (b) this is a bug fix, or (c) this does not need to be in the release notes. * [ ] The title of the PR states what changed and the related issues number (used for the release note). * -[X] The title of the PR conforms to the [Title of the PR](https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developer-guide/submit-your-pr/#title-of-the-pr) * [ ] I've included "Closes [ISSUE #]" or "Fixes [ISSUE #]" in the description to automatically close the associated issue. * [ ] I've updated both the CLI and UI to expose my feature, or I plan to submit a second PR with them. * [ ] Does this PR require documentation updates? * [ ] I've updated documentation as required by this PR. * -[X] I have signed off all my commits as required by [DCO](https://github.com/argoproj/argoproj/blob/master/community/CONTRIBUTING.md#legal) * [ ] I have written unit and/or e2e tests for my change. title: chore(deps): bump sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime from 0.21.0 to 0.22.0
body:
Bumps [sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime](https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime) from 0.21.0 to 0.22.0.
Release notes

Sourced from sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime's releases.

v0.22.0

🔆 Highlights

  • Client: Native support for Server-Side Apply (SSA) (#3253, #2981)
  • Update to k8s.io/* v1.34 dependencies (#3231, #3236, #3246, #3259, #3270, #3300)
  • Controller: Implement warmup support for controllers (#3192)
  • Priorityqueue: various improvements (#3289, #3290, #3243, #3250)

⚠️ Breaking changes

  • Update to k8s.io/* v1.34 dependencies by @​alvaroaleman @​troy0820 #3231, #3236, #3246, #3259, #3270, #3300
  • Client: Add native SSA support by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3253
  • Client: Default selector to Nothing if it is nil for MatchingLabelsSelector and MatchingFieldsSelector by @​acumino in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3279
  • Fakeclient: Add SSA support by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#2981
  • Fakeclient: Remove support for objects with pointer ObjectMeta by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3228
  • Fakeclient: Clear TypeMeta for structured objects by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3229
  • Priorityqueue: Make Priority option a pointer by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3289

✨ Features

  • Client: Add UnsafeDisableDeepCopy to GetOptions by @​jonathan-innis in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3227
  • Controller: Add a ReconciliationTimeout option by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3296
  • Controller: Implement warmup support for controllers by @​godwinpang in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3192
  • Envtest: Allow selection of binaries version by release series by @​cbandy in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3280
  • Manager: Add support for custom labels on leader election leases by @​DerekFrank in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3237
  • Priorityqueue: WithLowPriorityWhenUnchanged: Set Priority for all add methods by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3290
  • Webhooks: Handle panics during conversion more gracefully by @​sbueringer in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3278

🐛 Bugfixes

  • Envtest: Ensure cleanup validates etcd process state first by @​Danil-Grigorev in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3272
  • Envtest: Include listening address in kube-apiserver serving certificate by @​solidDoWant in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3284
  • Fakeclient: Fix some SSA-related bugs by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3268
  • Fakeclient: Update passed object in Apply by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3283
  • Fakeclient: Validate managed fields on init objects by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3282
  • Manager: Prevent goroutine leak on shutdown timeout by @​jingyih in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3247
  • Priorityqueue: Don't block on Get when queue is shutdown by @​dongjiang1989 in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3243
  • Priorityqueue: Shutdown on shutdown by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3250
  • Unit tests: Fix ginkgo panic in webhook integration test by @​sbueringer in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3288
  • Unit tests: Fix race condition in Warmup unit test by @​sbueringer in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3287

🌱 Other

  • Certwatcher: Add instance-specific logger with cert/key k/v pair by @​s-z-z in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3293
  • Certwatcher: Don't require leader election by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3273
  • Examples-builtin: Refactor controller setup to use builder pattern by @​s-z-z in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3265
  • Fix deprecation warnings by @​sbueringer in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3275
  • Update golangci-lint to v2.3.0 by @​dongjiang1989 in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3266
  • Unit tests: Stop using context.Background()/TODO() in tests by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3263

📖 Documentation

  • Clarify our versioning scheme by @​alvaroaleman in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3264
  • Clarify state of Warmup feature by @​sbueringer in kubernetes-sigs/controller-runtime#3299

title: feat(hydrator): dynamically manage README template from argocd-cm ConfigMap (#19067)
body:
Related Issue #19067

This PR introduces support for dynamically managing the content written to README.md that hydrator uses using the `argocd-cm` ConfigMap.

Changes:
1. Added Role and RoleBinding for the commit-server to allow access to the Kubernetes API.
2. The commit-server now subscribes to the `argocd-cm` configmap with an k8s informer to detect changes dynamically.
3. Added a new key `hydrator.readme.template` in `argocd-cm` to configure the README template string dynamically.
4. The existing README template remains as the default template. If `hydrator.readme.template` is empty, the default template will be applied.

Test:
I created the following Application and used the hydrator feature.
```yaml
apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
metadata:
  name: my-app
  namespace: argocd
spec:
  destination:
    namespace: default
    server: https://kubernetes.default.svc
  project: default
  sourceHydrator:
    drySource:
      path: helm-guestbook
      repoURL: https://github.com/gyu-young-park/argocd-example-apps.git
      targetRevision: HEAD
    syncSource:
      path: helm-guestbook
      targetBranch: dev
```

Next, I modified the configmap.
```sh
kubectl edit -n argocd configmaps argocd-cm
```

In argocd-cm, I changed hydrator.readme.template as follows:
```sh
data:
  hydrator.readme.template: "Hello World! Im Gyu! {{ .RepoURL }}"
```

The result submitted by hydrator can be found at the following link. You can see that the README.md correctly reflects the updated configmap information dynamically.
https://github.com/gyu-young-park/argocd-example-apps/commit/4a705c73060afbcf8f1783daafd5fa53a9c504db

Current Status
- Tests and documentation are not yet complete.
- Verified manually by building and running locally: changes to `hydrator.readme.template` in the configmap are correctly reflected in `README.md` of hydrator

This PR is still in an early stage, and I’d like to gather feedback on the implementation before proceeding with tests and documentation. Since I’m not yet very familiar with the argo-cd codebase, I find it difficult to identify potential issues in my changes or the right direction for improvements. I’d greatly appreciate your feedback and suggestions before moving forward.

title: feat(hydrator): add Helm support to Source Hydrator (#24228)
body:
## Summary

Add Helm support to Source Hydrator (alpha feature) to enable using Helm charts with environment-specific value files and parameters.

Currently, Source Hydrator only supports basic Git repository fields (`repoURL`, `targetRevision`, `path`) in the `DrySource` specification, making it impossible to use with Helm charts that require `valueFiles`, `parameters`, or other Helm-specific configurations.

This PR adds a `Helm` field to the `DrySource` type and updates the hydrator logic to properly handle Helm configurations, enabling teams to use Source Hydrator with Helm-based applications.

Closes #24228

## Changes

- **API**: Added `Helm *ApplicationSourceHelm` field to `DrySource` type in `pkg/apis/application/v1alpha1/types.go`
- **Logic**: Updated `controller/hydrator/hydrator.go` to copy Helm configuration from `DrySource` to the hydrated `ApplicationSource`

## Example Usage

**Before** (not supported):
```yaml
apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
spec:
  sourceHydrator:
    drySource:
      repoURL: https://github.com/example/charts.git
      targetRevision: main
      path: my-chart
      # ❌ helm field not supported
```

**After** (now supported):
```yaml
apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
spec:
  sourceHydrator:
    drySource:
      repoURL: https://github.com/example/charts.git
      targetRevision: main
      path: my-chart
      helm:  # ✅ Now works
        valueFiles:
          - values-prod.yaml
        parameters:
          - name: image.tag
            value: v1.2.3
        releaseName: my-release
```

## Use Case

Many teams use Helm with environment-specific value files (e.g., `values-dev.yaml`, `values-prod.yaml`). Without this support, Source Hydrator cannot be used for Helm applications, limiting its adoption for teams that want to use both Helm and the hydration workflow.

## Testing

- [x] Manual testing with Helm chart and multiple value files
- [x] Verified existing functionality remains unaffected
- [x] Confirmed `omitempty` tag ensures backward compatibility

## Future Work

- Add unit tests (will be included in follow-up PR)
- Update CRD schema (will be included in follow-up PR)  
- Add documentation (will be included in follow-up PR)

## Checklist

If the DCO action in the integration test fails, one or more of your commits are not signed off. Please click on the *Details* link next to the DCO action for instructions on how to resolve this.
-->

title: feat: Add gRPC health check in argocd-server
body:
Add gRPC health check to `argocd-server`, allowing it to properly respond with `SERVING` and the gRPC code `OK` on the `grpc.health.v1.Health/Check` path. This will enable health checkers and monitoring tools to correctly determine the gRPC service status.

It uses the standard gRPC health library `health/v1`, which is already implemented in `cmp-server`, `commit-server`, and `repo-server`.

Also updates the relevant documentation: [AWS Application Load Balancers (ALBs) And Classic ELB (HTTP Mode)](https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/operator-manual/ingress/#aws-application-load-balancers-albs-and-classic-elb-http-mode)

Fixes #24117

# What i have done

In `root.go`, I noticed that commands added to `NewCommand()` use inconsistent parameter naming in their function definitions. Some commands define their function parameters as `globalClientOpts` while others use `clientOpts`. 

For example, I found functions like:
- `func NewLoginCommand(globalClientOpts *argocdclient.ClientOptions) *cobra.Command`
- `func NewRepoCommand(clientOpts *argocdclient.ClientOptions) *cobra.Command`

then, I unified all command parameter definitions to consistently use `clientOpts` for better code consistency.

title: feat(actions): Add cloudnativepg reload, restart and promote actions
body: Adds specific actions for cloudnativepg that trigger the operator to execute an operational task that should not be governed by gitops. The following tasks are added: - Reload - this action instructs the cloudnativepg operator to check all Cluster child resources are still up-to-date - Restart - effectively kubectl rollout-restart but for the Cluster CRD - Promote - Starts the promotion process for promoting one of the healthy standby replicas to primary in one of three ways. You can either specify the full replica pod name, you can specify the replica pod instance number or you can specify any which will select the next available instance number automatically The promotion action is disabled if no healthy replicas are available to promote: The promotion action is enabled if there are healthy replicas: Before any promotion status: ``` targetPrimary: test-cluster-1 targetPrimaryTimestamp: "2025-08-18T16:34:03Z" currentPrimary: test-cluster-1 currentPrimaryTimestamp: "2025-08-18T16:34:08.311908Z" instancesStatus: healthy: - test-cluster-1 - test-cluster-2 ``` During promotion status: ``` targetPrimary: test-cluster-2 targetPrimaryTimestamp: "2025-08-18T16:41:38Z" currentPrimary: test-cluster-1 currentPrimaryTimestamp: "2025-08-18T16:34:08.311908Z" instancesStatus: healthy: - test-cluster-2 replicating: - test-cluster-1 ``` After promotion: ``` targetPrimary: test-cluster-2 targetPrimaryTimestamp: "2025-08-18T16:41:38Z" currentPrimary: test-cluster-2 currentPrimaryTimestamp: "2025-08-18T16:41:42.441994Z" instancesStatus: healthy: - test-cluster-1 - test-cluster-2 ``` The reload action triggers title: fix: replace grpc.NewClient (#19653)
body:
close: #19653 
<!--
Note on DCO:

If the DCO action in the integration test fails, one or more of your commits are not signed off. Please click on the *Details* link next to the DCO action for instructions on how to resolve this.
-->

I migrated from grpc.Dial to grpc.NewClient.

As part of this migration, I renamed BlockingDial to BlockingNewClient.
Based on the usage analysis, this function is only used by the apiclient in the ArgoCD CLI.

Therefore, I changed the custom dialer to reuse the initially created connection instead of creating a new one on each retry.

To replicate the previous WithBlock behavior, I added a waitForReady function that blocks until the connection is fully established.

P.S.
Would it be a good idea to migrate the grpc.Dial usage in the grpc-gateway generated code to grpc.NewClient as well?

title: fix(config): support accumulating multi-value flags (e.g., --header)
body:
### Problem
Currently, `LoadFlags()` parses environment variables into a map[string]string.
This causes the last occurrence of a flag (e.g., --header) to overwrite any previous ones.
For flags that can appear multiple times, this behavior is incorrect.

### Solution
- Updated flag handling to store values in `map[string][]string` instead of only one string.
- This allows flags like `--header` to accumulate multiple values instead of overwriting.
- Flags that are logically single-value (e.g., --loglevel, --retries) still behave as last-one-wins.

### Tests
- Added `env_multivalue_test.go` to verify behavior.
  - Multiple `--header` flags accumulate correctly.
  - `--header=foo --header=bar` works.
  - Comma-separated values still parse.
  - Other flags remain unchanged.
- Ran `go test ./util/config -v` → all tests pass.

### Notes
This resolves the issue of losing values when multiple flags are passed.
Users no longer need to rely on comma-separated workarounds.

title: fix: Ensure that symlink targets are not made absolute on extracting a tar (#24145)
body:
The out-of-bounds symlink validation of ArgoCD does not allow absolute symlink targets.
See https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/blob/2b1f5959bd3b108e032e7d66e2d5f50fc2610e05/util/app/path/path.go#L75

However, ArgoCD itself has converted relative symlink targets into absolute ones when extracting tar archives (which is used for example when using the new OCI repositories).

Please backport this to ArgoCD 3.1.x

Closes #24145

title: feat: ApplicationSet Phased Deployment Strategy with Pre/Post Hooks (Alpha)
body:
<!--
  Note on DCO:

  If the DCO action in the integration test fails, one or more of your commits are not signed off. Please click on the *Details* link next to the DCO action for instructions on how to resolve this.
  -->

  ## Summary

  This PR introduces a comprehensive **ApplicationSet Phase Deployment Strategy** feature that enables controlled, phased rollouts of applications across multiple clusters with advanced CLI management capabilities. This feature
  supports enterprise-scale deployments with security, performance, and operational controls.

  ## 🎯 Core Features

  ### Phase Deployment Strategy
  - **Phased rollouts**: Deploy applications in controlled phases across different cluster groups
  - **Pre/Post deployment hooks**: Command and HTTP-based hooks for validation and custom operations
  - **Health checks**: HTTP-based validation with configurable timeouts and retry logic
  - **Failure handling**: Configurable policies (fail, ignore, abort) with automatic rollback capabilities
  - **Progress tracking**: Real-time phase status monitoring and completion percentage

  ### CLI Management Interface
  - **Phase status tracking**: `argocd appset phase status` - Monitor current phase and overall progress
  - **Manual phase control**: `argocd appset phase advance/rollback` - Control phase transitions
  - **Deployment history**: `argocd appset phase history` - Audit trail of phase changes
  - **Enhanced listing**: Phase status integrated into `argocd appset list/get` commands
  - **Multiple output formats**: Table, JSON, and YAML output for automation

  ## 🔒 Security Enhancements

  ### Command Execution Security
  - Dangerous command detection (rm, sudo, curl) with warnings
  - Absolute path validation to prevent path traversal attacks
  - Environment variable limits (max 100) and sensitive variable detection
  - Command timeout validation with security limits (max 30 minutes)

  ### HTTP Security Validation
  - URL scheme validation (HTTP/HTTPS only)
  - Internal network address detection and warnings (localhost, private IPs)
  - HTTP header limits (max 50) and sensitive header detection
  - Response body size limits (1MB) to prevent memory exhaustion
  - HTTP timeout validation with security limits (max 10 minutes)

  ### Security Logging
  - Comprehensive warning logs for all security concerns
  - Structured logging with context for monitoring and alerting

  ## ⚡ Performance Optimizations

  ### Concurrent Execution
  - Phase checks run concurrently (max 10 simultaneous)
  - Phase hooks execute concurrently (max 5 simultaneous)
  - Semaphore-based throttling for resource management

  ### Scalability Improvements
  - Performance warnings for large deployments (>1000 applications per phase)
  - Context-aware operations with proper cancellation support
  - Optimized resource management for enterprise-scale usage

  ## 🔄 Version Compatibility

  - Semantic version validation with regex patterns
  - Minimum supported version documentation (v2.12.0)
  - Version annotation parsing and validation

  ## 📚 Comprehensive Documentation

  ### User Documentation
  - **CLI Guide** (`docs/operator-manual/applicationset/CLI-Phase-Deployment.md`): Complete CLI usage examples and workflows
  - **Generator Guide** (`docs/operator-manual/applicationset/Generators-Phase-Deployment.md`): Configuration and strategy documentation
  - **Security Guidelines** (`docs/operator-manual/applicationset/phase-deployment-security.md`): Security best practices and configuration
  - **Performance Guidelines** (`docs/operator-manual/applicationset/phase-deployment-performance.md`): Optimization strategies and monitoring

  ### Technical Documentation
  - **Strategy Proposal** (`docs/proposals/phased-deployment-strategy.md`): Technical design and implementation details

  ### Examples
  - **8 comprehensive examples** in `applicationset/examples/` covering:
    - Simple phase deployment
    - Advanced multi-cluster scenarios
    - CLI-focused demonstrations
    - Hook-based validations
    - Matrix and percentage-based deployments

  ## 🛠 Implementation Details

  ### API Changes
  - Enhanced `GeneratorDeploymentStrategy` type with phase deployment support
  - New phase deployment configuration structures
  - Backward-compatible API extensions

  ### CLI Implementation
  - New `argocd appset phase` command group with subcommands:
    - `status` - Show phase status and progress
    - `advance` - Move to next phase
    - `rollback` - Return to previous phase
    - `history` - Show deployment history
  - Enhanced existing commands with phase information display
  - Support for dry-run operations and multiple output formats

  ### Generator Implementation
  - Phase deployment generator with concurrent execution
  - HTTP check system with security validation
  - Hook execution system with command and HTTP support
  - Progress tracking and annotation management

  ## 🧪 Testing

  - Comprehensive unit tests for all new functionality
  - HTTP check validation tests
  - Phase deployment logic tests
  - CLI command tests with mock scenarios
  - Security validation tests

  ## 📋 Configuration Examples

  ### Basic Phase Deployment
  ```yaml
  apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
  kind: ApplicationSet
  spec:
    generators:
    - clusters:
        selector:
          matchLabels:
            environment: "*"
      deploymentStrategy:
        type: phaseDeployment
        phases:
        - name: "development"
          targets:
          - clusters: ["dev-cluster"]
          checks:
          - name: "health-check"
            type: "http"
            http:
              url: "https://{{name}}.dev.example.com/health"
          waitDuration: "30s"
        - name: "production"
          targets:
          - clusters: ["prod-cluster"]
          onFailure:
            action: "rollback"

  CLI Usage

  # Create ApplicationSet with phase deployment
  argocd appset create phase-deployment.yaml

  # Monitor phase status
  argocd appset phase status my-app

  # Advance to next phase
  argocd appset phase advance my-app

  # View deployment history
  argocd appset phase history my-app
```

  🚀 Benefits

  - Risk Reduction: Gradual rollouts minimize blast radius of failures
  - Operational Control: Manual or automated phase advancement
  - Enterprise Ready: Security and performance controls for large-scale deployments
  - Observability: Comprehensive monitoring and audit trails
  - Developer Experience: Intuitive CLI interface with multiple output formats

title: docs: Update documentation for http-retry-max cli option
body:
Initial documentation implies that --http-retry-max applies solely to initial HTTP connection issues. However, given we use the Hashicorp go-httpretryablehttp library, we also get "free" retries for 5xx error codes (outside of 501). See https://github.com/hashicorp/go-retryablehttp/blob/main/README.md?plain=1#L17. As such, we should let people know that the flag covers both cases.

I don't believe this rises to the level of needing to be mentioned in release notes.

title: feat(controller): add PostSyncHookError condition when PostSync hooks fail (Closes #14679)
body: Closes #23719 ### Summary Add PostSyncHookError Application condition. On each sync, if any PostSync hook fails: - SetHealth to Degraded - Add/refresh PostSyncHookError with aggregated messages `(namespace/name: reason)` When no PostSync failures remain, clear the condition. This also surfaces in metrics via argocd_app_condition{condition="PostSyncHookError", ...} = 1. ### Motivation Teams often run E2E/smoke tests in PostSync Jobs. When those tests fail (e.g., BackoffLimitExceeded), the failure is visible in the manifest, but not exposed as a dedicated condition/metric. This PR makes those failures observable and alertable. ### Changes - controller/appcontroller.go: detect failed PostSync hooks in the latest sync and manage the PostSyncHookError condition; set Health to Degraded while failures exist; clear the condition when resolved. - pkg/apis/application/v1alpha1/types.go: add ApplicationConditionPostSyncHookError (condition type) so it’s exported via metrics. ### Screenshots / Verification 1. UI—Health & Conditions - App health shows Degraded; 1 Error is displayed in App Conditions panel. - Screenshot: 2. Metrics—argocd_app_condition - `argocd_app_condition{condition="PostSyncHookError",name="test-post-job-failed-test",namespace="argo",project="default"} 1` - Screenshot: 3. Application conditions detail modal - Aggregated message like: `PostSync hook failed: default/fail-postsync: Job has reached the specified backoff limit` - Screenshot: ### Related - Issue: https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/23719 - Slack discussion: https://cloud-native.slack.com/archives/C01TSERG0KZ/p1752056389728489 Checklist: * [x] Either (a) I've created an [enhancement proposal](https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/new/choose) and discussed it with the community, (b) this is a bug fix, or (c) this does not need to be in the release notes. * [x] The title of the PR states what changed and the related issues number (used for the release note). * [x] The title of the PR conforms to the [Title of the PR](https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developer-guide/submit-your-pr/#title-of-the-pr) * [x] I've included "Closes [ISSUE #]" or "Fixes [ISSUE #]" in the description to automatically close the associated issue. * [x] I've updated both the CLI and UI to expose my feature, or I plan to submit a second PR with them. * [x] Does this PR require documentation updates? * [ ] I've updated documentation as required by this PR. * [x] I have signed off all my commits as required by [DCO](https://github.com/argoproj/argoproj/blob/master/community/CONTRIBUTING.md#legal) * [x] I have written unit and/or e2e tests for my change. title: fix: Missing JWT signature check
body:
https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/blob/e5417e1eb383fa72f00f7a18bd29af3047ce4bf4/cmd/argocd/commands/login.go#L143-L145
Applications decoding a JSON Web Token (JWT) may be vulnerable when the signature is not correctly verified.


Fix the problem, the code should parse and verify the JWT signature using a method that checks the signature, such as `jwt.ParseWithClaims`. This requires providing a key function that returns the expected verification key (e.g., the OIDC provider’s public key). In the context of OIDC, the correct way is to use the OIDC provider’s verifier to verify the ID token, which also checks the signature and claims. The code already obtains an OIDC provider object (`provider` at line 139), which can be used to create a verifier. The fix is to use `provider.Verifier()` to verify the ID token and extract the claims, instead of using `ParseUnverified`.

**Steps:**
- Replace the use of `jwt.NewParser().ParseUnverified` with OIDC provider’s verifier to verify the ID token.
- Use the verified token’s claims for display.
- Add any necessary imports (none needed, as `github.com/coreos/go-oidc/v3/oidc` is already imported).
- No changes to the rest of the authentication flow.


#### References
JWT IO: [Introduction to JSON Web Tokens](https://jwt.io/introduction)
jwt-go: [Documentation](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/golang-jwt/jwt/v5)
Go JOSE: [Documentation](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/go-jose/go-jose/v3)

title: feat(ui): search filter by target revision
body: Closes #23704 Hi, As you can see from the issue link, I implemented a feature that allows filtering by target revision in the Argo CD Application dashboard. To support both multi-source and single-source Applications, I created a utility function that handles both cases. I designed the utility function to return the appropriate source based on priority. If a `sourceHydrator` exists, it takes precedence over all others. (as list) If not, it falls back to `multi-source` first, and then to `single-source`. I've attached a short video and some screenshots to demonstrate how it works. Please take a look and review the code when you have a moment. Thanks! ``` # multi source application manifest example project: default destination: server: https://kubernetes.default.svc namespace: default sources: - repoURL: https://github.com/argoproj/argocd-example-apps path: kustomize-guestbook targetRevision: agaudreault-patch-1 # or HEAD in test - repoURL: https://github.com/argoproj/argocd-example-apps path: jsonnet-guestbook targetRevision: HEAD # or agaudreault-patch-1 in test ``` ### Demo video https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fecf1525-a8cc-4f5b-84aa-7069f3f5902e ### Demo screenshots Checklist: * [ ] Either (a) I've created an [enhancement proposal](https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/new/choose) and discussed it with the community, (b) this is a bug fix, or (c) this does not need to be in the release notes. * [ ] The title of the PR states what changed and the related issues number (used for the release note). * [x] The title of the PR conforms to the [Title of the PR](https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developer-guide/submit-your-pr/#title-of-the-pr) * [x] I've included "Closes [ISSUE #]" or "Fixes [ISSUE #]" in the description to automatically close the associated issue. * [ ] I've updated both the CLI and UI to expose my feature, or I plan to submit a second PR with them. * [ ] Does this PR require documentation updates? * [ ] I've updated documentation as required by this PR. * [x] I have signed off all my commits as required by [DCO](https://github.com/argoproj/argoproj/blob/master/community/CONTRIBUTING.md#legal) * [ ] I have written unit and/or e2e tests for my change. title: fix: improve CMP logging and error messages
body:
## Summary

This PR addresses issue #12144 by improving CMP (Config Management Plugin) logging and error messages in three key areas:

- **Standardize error message wording**: Consistently use "could not" instead of "couldn't" throughout the codebase for better consistency
- **Include application name in error messages**: Add application name to CMP error messages to make debugging easier when reviewing argocd-repo-server logs  
- **Improve error message clarity**: Replace generic "plugin sidecar failed" message with more descriptive "CMP processing failed" message as suggested in the issue

## Changes

### Error Message Standardization
- `util/app/discovery/discovery.go`: Use "could not" for consistency
- `util/oidc/oidc.go`: Standardize "couldn't" to "could not" in error messages  
- `applicationset/utils/utils.go`: Fix typo "coundn't" and standardize error messages to "could not"
- `applicationset/controllers/applicationset_controller.go`: Use "could not" for consistency

### CMP Error Message Improvements
- `reposerver/repository/repository.go`: Include application name and use clearer error wording

## Before/After

**Before:**
```
err = fmt.Errorf("plugin sidecar failed. %s", err.Error())
```

**After:**
```
err = fmt.Errorf("CMP processing failed for application %q: %w", q.AppName, err)
```

This results in error messages changing from:
```
error="plugin sidecar failed. could not find cmp-server plugin with name 'example' supporting the given repository"
```

To:
```
error="CMP processing failed for application \"my-app\": could not find cmp-server plugin with name 'example' supporting the given repository"
```

## Test plan

- [x] Existing tests pass
- [x] Error message changes are consistent with codebase patterns
- [x] CMP-related code compiles and functions correctly

Fixes #12144

title: feat: Implement Altinity clickhouse-operator CRD health checks
body:
# Add custom health checks for ClickHouse and ClickHouseKeeper installations

## Description

This PR adds custom health checks for ClickHouse and ClickHouseKeeper installations from Altinity. These health checks will help Argo CD users better understand the status of their ClickHouse deployments and prevent race conditions by providing proper support for sync waves.

## Changes

### Added Health Checks

1. **clickhouse.altinity.com/ClickHouseInstallation**
   - Evaluates `status.status` field
   - Returns `Healthy` when status is `Completed`
   - Returns `Progressing` when status is `InProgress` or not yet available
   - Returns `Degraded` for any other status value

2. **clickhouse-keeper.altinity.com/ClickHouseKeeperInstallation**
   - Evaluates `status.status` field
   - Returns `Healthy` when status is `Completed`
   - Returns `Progressing` when status is `InProgress` or not yet available
   - Returns `Degraded` for any other status value

## Testing

Each health check includes comprehensive test cases covering:
- Healthy state (status: Completed)
- Progressing state (status: InProgress)
- Degraded state (status: Failed)
- Progressing state (no status field)

All health checks have been tested and validated to work correctly with the provided test data.

## Related Issues

Closes [ISSUE https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/24015]
This addresses the need for proper health monitoring of ClickHouse installations in Argo CD applications and helps prevent race conditions during deployment by ensuring proper sync wave coordination.

## Notes

These health checks follow the same pattern as other custom health checks in the repository (e.g., cert-manager.io/Certificate) and use the standard Lua health check format. By providing accurate health status information, these checks enable Argo CD to properly coordinate sync waves and prevent race conditions during ClickHouse deployment and scaling operations.

title: feat(reposerver): pass otel tracing propagation carrier via env (#23988)
body:
<!--
Note on DCO:

If the DCO action in the integration test fails, one or more of your commits are not signed off. Please click on the *Details* link next to the DCO action for instructions on how to resolve this.
-->

with argocd plugin feature, arbitrary code can be executed, which can also make HTTP requests. Since ArgoCD already supports OpenTelemetry tracing, if tracing context is passed to plugin, debugging would be much easier.

this PR makes ArgoCD RepoServer pass propagation data to the plugin using environment variables, following opentelemetry specification: https://opentelemetry.io/docs/specs/otel/context/env-carriers/

this Closes #23988

title: chore: migrate to pnpm
body:
This is a continuation of the original "migrate to Yarn 2" task #5279, but rather than migrate to Yarn 2 (there's been a couple of jumps since), this rather migrates to [pnpm](https://pnpm.io/).

Why? Mostly since Yarn 1 has been EOL'd for quite some time, and hasn't had any commits for over a year. Moving to Yarn > 1 is likely a big of a change as moving to pnpm anyway. The biggest [benefits](https://pnpm.io/motivation) are for development, where we can get disk-size and speed savings from not having to download multiple node_modules dependencies twice (to be fair, this is only a real benefit if a developer has multiple JS repos that happen to make use of the same dependencies).

The diff looks scarily large, but almost all of it is adding a pnpm lock file and removing the yarn lock file. I tried this out locally and it works 👌. I still need to tweak the GH Action workflows since the caching needs fixing, but should be relatively minor to handle. 

Changes needed, apart from moving to pnpm itself:

* Added missing dependencies (pnpm is much stricter on needing to include transitive dependencies than yarn or npm)
* Removed `yarn` dev dependency (not needed anymore obvs)
* pnpm resolved `sass` to a newer version, meaning that I needed to add some extra configuration to webpack in order for it not to display a bunch of deprecation warnings in the dev screen
* Likewise, pnpm resolved `webpack-dev-server` to a newer Webpack version, where any error messages gets displayed in a big obnoxious modal. I needed to exclude 401 errors from that (otherwise logout and permission denied will display the full stacktrace across the screen. Can be clicked away but still obnoxious). This is a dev-only setting which doesn't affect this when built for prod.
* Moved TS isolated modules from Jest to `tsconfig.json` 
* `transformIgnorePatterns` needs to account for the new locations where pnpm places dependencies within `node_modules`
* Pinned `formidable` to `2.1.2`, since bumping it (as pnpm desires) seems to lead to a whole train of dependencies needing to be upgraded
* Pinned `@types/dagre` to `0.7.42`, since bumping it to a newer version leads to type breakages

title: fix(api): user with global access should get `NotFound` instead of `PermissionDenied`
body:
The current behavior, while functional, is a usability bug. If a user, for instance users with the `role:admin` permissions have access to all applications, then they should not be getting a `PermissionDenied` if they do not provide an optional `project` on the API call. 

It is wrong to return `PermissionDenied`, because the user has permissions. This prevent a user to know if an application exist. The workaround is to use `kubectl` to  get the application by name, or use the Argo API LIST to get all the applications and filter by name. While filtering by name is possible and not too expensive, it is a very surprising usage of the API.

Since the RBAC enforcement is always project scoped in the case of applications, and that `*` is not a valid character in k8s object name, we can safely determine a global access by looking at the `*/*` object name. In that case, a user with global access will receive a`NotFound` result if the app does not exist.

title: feat(server): add `--request-timeout` options that only exist in docs (#18198)
body:
Fixes [#18198] ### Problem The `--request-timeout` option for the ArgoCD server only exists in the [docs](https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/operator-manual/server-commands/argocd-server/) and has not been actually implemented. ### Impact By using Context, processes will terminate if they exceed the specified requestTimeout. ### Changed I understand that gRPC-gateway warpped HTTP requests. However, a gap could exist where timeouts aren't applied until the request reaches the interceptor. This helps prevent delays if the gRPC-gateway conversion or other HTTP processing steps take too long. - `requestTimeoutGRPCInterceptor`, `requestTimeoutHTTPInterceptor` : - a new context valid for the specified duration is created using `context.WithTimeout` - request is automatically canceled if it doesn't complete within the timeout period - `newGRPCServer`: applied as a global timeout for gRPC requests - `newHTTPServer`: applied to explicitly configured HTTP paths such as `/api/badge`, `common.LogoutEndpoint`, `/terminal`, and `/api/webhook`
Interceptors have also been applied to handlers within `registerDexHandlers` that communicate with the OIDC Provider. - `dexutil.NewDexHTTPReverseProxy` - `server.ssoClientApp.HandleLogin` - `server.ssoClientApp.HandleCallback`
### Test ``` go test ./server -run TestRequestTimeoutGRPCInterceptor go test ./server -run TestRequestTimeoutHTTPInterceptor ``` you can simply use: ``` make test-local ```

title: docs: add TLS configuration quick reference table for easier understanding
body:
<!--
Note on DCO:

If the DCO action in the integration test fails, one or more of your commits are not signed off. Please click on the *Details* link next to the DCO action for instructions on how to resolve this.
-->

## Summary

This PR adds **TLS Configuration Quick Reference tables** to improve the usability of the TLS configuration documentation.

## Motivation

The current TLS configuration documentation contains comprehensive information but lacks a quick reference for users to understand the differences between ArgoCD components at a glance. Users often need to read through lengthy sections to find specific information about:
- Which components support certificate hot reload
- Required secret names for each component  
- Required SAN entries
- Inter-component TLS parameters

## Changes

Added two comparison tables to `docs/operator-manual/tls.md`:

1. **Certificate Configuration Overview Table**
   - Shows hot reload support, secret names, SAN requirements
   - Provides quick comparison across `argocd-server`, `argocd-repo-server`, `argocd-dex-server`

2. **Inter-Component TLS Parameters Table** 
   - Shows strict TLS and plaintext parameters
   - Clarifies default behavior (non-validating TLS)

## Before vs After

### Before: Current comprehensive documentation
![before](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cb5fcd85-5f2f-4bc0-8974-57dd79328458)

### After: Enhanced with quick reference tables
![after](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/530f39fb-eaf3-43b3-b2f3-8583e59f869e)

## Table Preview

### Certificate Configuration Overview
![cert-table](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/987ee4fa-3821-492a-9185-fe9ee0fbf428)

### Inter-Component TLS Parameters  
![component-table](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/37a09cc8-7357-4272-9147-1a12333ac305)

## Benefits

- **Improved usability**: Users can quickly find relevant information
- **Better onboarding**: New users understand TLS architecture faster  
- **Enhanced troubleshooting**: Clear overview helps identify configuration issues
- **Reduced support burden**: Fewer questions about certificate configuration

title: feat(kustomize): add support for components by reference (#23872)
body:
Following #21674 which allowed ignoring components and #23486 which allowed having components specified in a monorepo, this allows specifying components by reference the same way that helm values files can be specified. This is useful for people that store components in branches or are doing testing by using branches against the main application components. Fixes #23872.

title: fix: Ensure application sets in custom namespace can be upserted
body:
Fixes the following error which is returned when trying to upsert an ApplicationSet in a custom namespace. 

```
rpc error: code = Internal desc = unable to check existing ApplicationSet details: applicationsets.argoproj.io "test" not found
```

Related to https://github.com/argoproj-labs/terraform-provider-argocd/issues/658

Should be cherry-picked onto all active release branches.
